THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
A.  Justification 
1.  The proposed transaction technical assistance facility (TA facility) will provide project 
1.  The proposed transaction technical assistance facility (TA facility) will provide project 
preparation support to a series of projects, initially comprising (i) Gansu Rural Vitalization and 
preparation support to a series of projects, initially comprising (i) Gansu Rural Vitalization and 
Integrated  Industry  Development,  (ii)  Shanxi  Low-Carbon  and  Beautiful      Villages

3.  In the PRC, initial project proposals are prepared by local governments or other project 
implementation entities (such as project executing agencies) with the support of design institutes, 
local technical entities that have acquired significant capacity over time. However, capacity to 
conduct economic and financial due diligence, environment and social safeguard due diligence as 
well as sector assessments and overall sector governance can still be improved. A new trend is 
therefore to jointly develop multi-sector projects where cross-sector integration and oversight can 
improve the design, effectiveness and sustainability of the ADB-financed investments. 
 
4.  Engaging consultants to work on multiple projects can improve efficiency in preparation; 
advanced planning and scoping of sector work; and better project readiness. Moreover, it increases 
ADB's  responsiveness  to  government's  priorities  that  quickly  arise  due  to  the  fast  pace  of 
development. The proposed arrangement also requires consultants, the government counterparts, 
and ADB staff to work seamlessly as one team.  
 
5.  The proposed TA facility will provide project preparation support (planning and sector 
assessments,  due  diligence  work,  and  training  of  government  staff  to  support  their  project 
preparation activities) for four projects in the pipeline for 2021 approval. As projects will require 
economic, financial, environment and safeguard specialists, the TA facility approach is suitable to 
(i) enhance operational efficiency in project preparation; (ii) gain synergies from working with the 
same consultants; (iii) reduce recruitment time of consultants by allowing consultants to be retained 
on a long-term basis; and (iv) strengthen coordination between ADB's preparatory activities and 
design institutes' work. The TA facility will result in efficient and strategic implementation of a 
consolidated TA to support project preparation aiming at faster delivery of innovative projects, 
                     
1  ADB. 2016. Transforming Partnership: People’s Republic of China and Asian Development Bank. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: People's Republic of China, 2019–2021. Manila.

2 
quicker and more flexible responsiveness to support lending operations, and higher readiness of 
approved projects.  
 
6.  The TA facility will finance a pool of green projects cutting across sectors to be implemented 
by local governments. The main sub-sectors include: (i) road transport (non-urban), and water transport 
(non-urban), (ii) water and sanitation, (iii) clean energy, (iv) waste management, and (v) environment. 
The investment program is aligned with the following impact: Increased investment to promote green 
growth through air-, water-, and land- quality improvements as well as lower greenhouse gas 
emissions. The outcome will be an enhanced green, low-carbon and sustainable infrastructure sector 
development in the PRC. Outputs include (i) green and bankable infrastructure projects developed,  
(ii)  increased  participation  of  financial  institutions  (FI)  in  sustainable  projects;  and  (ii)  capacity 
development of government and Fl to screen, appraise and support sustainable projects. Gender 
mainstreaming will be a critical analytical and design tool to ensure the ensuing projects are inclusive.  
 
B.  Ensuing projects 
7.  The proposed ensuing projects under the TA facility are fully aligned with ADB's country 
partnership strategy for PRC (footnote 1) and the strategic priorities of Strategy 2030.3 The TA 
facility is classified as complex because three of the four initial projects are rated complex. 
 
Table 1: Indicative TA Activities Implementation Period and Budget Allocation  
  TA Budget  
TA Activity   Title   Year  (‘000)  
1   Gansu Rural Vitalization and Integrated Industry Development    2019–2021  450 
2   Shanxi Low-Carbon and Beautiful Villages Development    2019–2021  450 
3   Guangxi-Guilin Comprehensive Ecological Rehabilitation   2019–2021  450 
4   Heilongjiang Regional Economic Cooperation   2019–2021  450 
  Total    1,800 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
Gansu Rural Vitalization4 and Integrated Industry Development   
  
8.  Gansu  is  one  of  the  poorest  provinces  in  the  PRC  with  a  low  level  of  urbanization.  
The proposed project will promote rural vitalization using new models for industrial integration to 
achieve comprehensive poverty eradication in the province. The project is aligned with the Gansu 
Rural Revitalization paper (2018).5 The project aims to increase rural income channels by developing 
local core industries and improving agricultural practices and developing tourism as a key business 
activity.  
 
9.  The project scope entails (i) construction of low carbon infrastructure and public service 
facilities; (ii) industry revitalization; (iii) ecological revitalization towards improved environment;  
(iv) cultural revitalization; and (v) talent revitalization. The project is categorized as low-risk. 
  
Shanxi Low-Carbon and Beautiful Villages Development  
  
10.  The proposed Shanxi Low-Carbon and Beautiful Village Development Project aims to 
support Shanxi Provincial government in their effort to build more balanced and inclusive growth 
                     
3  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030. Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
4  ADB’s Memorandum of Understanding with the Ministry of Finance and National Development and Reform 
Commission on Rural Vitalization. https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/related/122921/NDRC-MOF-
ADB_Rural%20Revitalization%20MoU%20%28Signed%29.pdf 
5  Gansu Provincial Government. 2018. Implementation of Rural Vitalization Strategy. Gansu.

3 
particularly in rural areas with provision of modern and low-carbon infrastructure while enhancing 
efficient and sustainable energy and resource use. Based on abundant coal and other mineral 
resources, the economy of Shanxi province is mainly driven by heavy industries such as coal and 
chemical production, power generation, and metal refining accounting for 70% of provincial gross 
domestic  product.  Carbon,  energy  and  resource  intensive  industrialization  brought  serious 
environmental degradation and pollution, greenhouse gases emissions, resource depletion but also 
unbalanced growth leaving Shanxi to face substantial development challenges. With the PRC 
government designating Shanxi as the first national-level pilot province for comprehensive reforms 
in a resource-based economy, Shanxi province is committed to reform and set its priority focus on 
its least developed areas. 
 
11.  The proposed project aims to demonstrate low-carbon and beautiful village and county 
models that transform poor rural villages with limited public utility services into modern, green, 
clean, and low-carbon villages by advancing infrastructure while promoting efficient resource and 
energy use through innovative technical and business processes. A range of low-carbon and 
beautiful village models will be developed in various locations in south Shanxi province, which 
would be customized to their own unique conditions, built-in systems requirements, and resource 
availabilities. The project is categorized as complex.   
 
Guangxi–Guilin Comprehensive Ecological Rehabilitation Project   
  
12.  Guilin is a city located in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region on the Lijang River. The city 
is one of the PRC’s most popular tourist destinations receiving about 5 million tourists annually.  
The project’s impact is to alleviate poverty in impoverished counties of Guilin. The outcome is to 
improve and rehabilitate the Lijiang River and restore ancient villages. The outputs are (i) ecological 
protection and restoration of the Lijang River; (ii) development of ancient villages and towns;  
(iii) construction and management of Lijiang River infrastructure and tourism service support facilities; 
(iv) construction of pedestrian and non-motorized facilities along the river; (v) protection and repair of 
ancient villages in Longsheng autonomous county; and (vi) capacity strengthening.   
 
13.  Specifically, the proposed project will improve water quality and reduce water pollution in 
the  Lijiang  River,  reduce  air  pollution,  promote  green  transportation,  and  develop  targeted 
measures for poverty reduction in several impoverished counties in Guilin. It will also support the 
key strategic priorities of mitigating climate change, promoting environmental sustainability, and 
poverty alleviation. The project is categorized as complex.  
 
Heilongjiang Regional Economic Cooperation Project  
  
14.  The proposed project will enhance economic cooperation among the PRC, Mongolia and 
the Russian Federation taking advantage of developed transport corridors and transforming them 
into economic corridors. Smooth and efficient flow of goods and people in the corridors will be 
improved through socially-sustainable, environmentally-friendly, and energy-efficient investments. 
The corridors will also provide alternative seaport access to Mongolia and enhance economic 
development  to  the  country’s  eastern  region,  traversed  by  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC) Corridor 4c.   
 
15.  The project will be concentrated in the border cities of Heihe and Suifenhe in Heilongjiang 
Province. The project will introduce innovative technology in the areas of logistics and supply chain 
management, urban utility supply, and urban transport. It will contribute to low-carbon development 
of the economic corridors, food security, and the development of livable cities. The project will 
provide credit to small- and medium-sized enterprises either (i) registered or physically located in

4 
the two border municipalities or (ii) involved in trade, manufacturing, agriculture or tourism business 
using the financial intermediation loan modality. The project is categorized as complex.  
   
16.  The project preparation could be expanded for additional ensuing projects for preparation 
in 2020 and 2021. These projects are likely to require similar sector, financial, economic, environment, 
poverty, and social assessments, and governance, anti-corruption and integrity, legal and regulatory 
due diligence. Framework contracts could be introduced to expedite recruitment of consultants.

17.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 2.

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.  
   
D.  Cost and Financing    
18.  The TA Facility is estimated to cost $2.0 million, inclusive of the value of the government in-
kind contribution, of which $1.8 million will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The overall cost estimates and financing plan are 
listed in Appendix 1. For TA activities for each ensuing project, the government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of counterpart staff, office facilities, domestic transportation, provision of available 
relevant government data and studies for the TA consultants' use, and other in-kind contributions for 
an estimated total value of $200,000. The government has been informed that approval of the TA facility 
does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.

5 
E.  Implementation Arrangements  
19.  ADB will administer the TA facility and the TA activities for each ensuing project working closely 
with its PRC counterparts. The East Asia Department's Sustainable Infrastructure Division (EASI) will 
lead TA implementation, i.e. selecting, administering, and supervising the consultants and their outputs 
to be delivered for the respective projects, including final evaluation of consultants. Table 3 provides 
further details on the proposed executing and implementation agencies for each ensuing project.  
 
Table 3: Implementation Arrangements

a Method of engagement to be determined in each TA activity for the ensuing project proposal.   
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.  
 
20.  TA activities for each ensuing project will require a team of international and national 
consultants to be engaged by ADB. Consulting firms and individual consultants will be recruited 
based on the requirements of each ensuing project, in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and associated Staff Instructions. The fields, duration of 
engagement and related costs of the expertise in Appendix 2 are indicative and estimates will be 
finalized prior to approval of each ensuing TA activity in consultation with the government teams. 
TA activities would start after ADB approves the loan project concept paper of an ensuing project. 
Consulting firms will be engaged following the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a 
quality-cost  ratio  of  90:10  using  full  or  simplified  technical  proposal  procedures,  as 
appropriate. Individual consultants' selection method will be used to provide specialized technical 
inputs to fulfill ADB’s advanced planning and sector work, due diligence requirements, and enhance 
project readiness.

6 
21.  Contract  options  may  include  time-based,  output-based  (lump-sum),  or  framework 
contracts, for consulting services under the TA facility. When the preparation of loans to be 
supported by the proposed TA facility require the same set of expertise, important synergies can 
be achieved from engaging the same consultants. Lumpsum travel will be encouraged for both firms 
and individual consultants as well as allowance based travel for local transport. 
 
II.    THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the provision 
of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,800,000 on a grant basis to the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China for Preparing Sustainable Development Projects, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.   
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
